concept.title: Getting information (general)
concept.shortdesc: Sources of information about DITA and DITA Open Toolkit.

prolog.author: Anna van Raaphorst
Richard Johnson
prolog.publisher: OASIS (Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards)

keywords.indexterm: getting information about DITA Open Toolkit

conbody.p:
Sections in this topic:
General information and FAQs
Tools, downloads
Training, education
Consulting
Standards and product releases
Usage information
User groups, forums
Conferences

section.title: General Information and Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) about DITA and DITA Open Toolkit

stentry.p: dita.xml.org: Official DITA community gathering place and information resource for the DITA OASIS Standard
Includes a knowledge base, a wiki, news items about DITA, events, products and services, case studies, user groups, forums, blogs, and a resource directory. Hosted by OASIS.
Cover Pages: Articles, presentations, and facts about DITA
Hosted by OASIS.
IBM site containing a collection of information about DITA
Download site for the Toolkit and related/prerequisite software
alphaWorks IBM TaskModeler: An Eclipse-based tool for rapidly creating and analyzing models of human activity for DITA and user experience design
IBM download site: Collection of DITA downloads

p.cite: Introduction to DITA: A User Guide to the Darwin Information Typing Architecture

stentry.p: Book (level: beginner). Authors: Jennifer Linton and Kylene Bruski. Publisher: Comtech Services, Colorado, 2006. Task-oriented approach to learning DITA. Authored using DITA markup and methodology in a variety of XML editors. Published using the Blast Radius and Mekon FrameMaker plugin in the DITA 1.2 Open Toolkit.

cite.b: Introduction to the Darwin Information Typing Architecture

stentry.p: Article (level: beginner). Authors: Eric Hennum, Don Day, John Hunt, and Dave Schell. Publisher: IBM, updated September 2005. Roadmap for the Darwin Information Typing Architecture: what it is and how it applies to technical documentation. Also a product of the architecture, having been written entirely in XML and produced using the principles described.

cite.b: Design patterns for information architecture with DITA map domains

stentry.p: Article (level: intermediate). Authors: Eric Hennum, Don Day, John Hunt, and Dave Schell. Publisher: IBM, updated September 2005. Explains the design technique for creating a DITA map domain.

cite.b: An XML-based information architecture for learning content

stentry.p: Part 1: A DITA specialization design. Article (level: intermediate). Authors: Robert Bernard and John P. Hunt. Publisher: IBM, August 2005. How topic-based DITA XML can provide the basis for developing an information architecture for single-sourced XML learning content.

cite.b: An XML-based information architecture for learning content

stentry.p: Part 2: A DITA content pilot. Article (level: intermediate). Authors: John P. Hunt and Robert Bernard. Publisher: IBM, August 2005. How topic-based DITA XML can provide the basis for developing an information architecture for single-sourced XML learning content.

section.title: DITA and DITA Open Toolkit standards and product releases

stentry.p: Lists of proposed and committed features for future releases.
Bugs, support requests, patches, feature requests.

p.b: OASIS DITA Open Toolkit project home
OASIS DITA Open Toolkit 1.3 features and issues tracking
DITA Open Toolkit developers mailing list

stentry.p: OASIS Standard, 09 May 2005.
OASIS Standard, 09 May 2005.

Apache Derby, an Apache database subproject, is a relational database implemented entirely in Java, and available under the Apache license, version 2.0. The Derby documentation manuals are sourced in DITA.
For an overview of the documentation, see .
For the DITA source files, see .

p.b: Forum for DITA questions and discussion

stentry.p: List of DITA user and interest groups (by location)
DITA forums on sourceforge.net (there are three forums: developers, help, and open discussion)

p.note: The following DITA-related conferences were or will be held in 2006. Some tentative dates are also given for 2007. For the latest information about these conferences, see the referenced websites.

stentry.p: Date: December 5-7. Location: Boston. Audience: Those who want to use XML and related technologies.

Date: November 2-3. Location: Frankfurt. Audience: Those who are interested in implementing XML DITA or learning more about this new standard for topic-based authoring. Conference organizer: Center for Information Development Management.

Date: July 27-29. Location: Raleigh, NC. Focus: Presentations on real-world use of XML. Conference organizer: Tri-XML, an interest group for the Research Triangle area, NC USA that focuses on educating members in XML-related technologies and potential uses.
Date: June 20-21. Location:London. Focus: Seeks to critique the established business justification for the adoption of both XML and DITA in organizational publishing.
Date: May 16-19. Location: Amsterdam. XTech 2007: Paris. Audience: Developers, information designers and managers working with web and standards-based technologies.
Date: April 3-5. Location: San Francisco, CA. CMS 07: March 26-28, Boston, MA. Conference organizer: Center for Information Development Management (CIDM).
Date: March 23-25. Location: Raleigh, NC. DITA 2007 (West Coast), February, California. DITA 2007 (East Coast), fall, Florida (tentative). Conference organizer: Bright Path Solutions.
